TextView.android:text: Globalisation, Urbanisation and the search for better livelihood has led to an increase of migrant labourers. In some regions of India, three out of four households include a migrant. Migrant wage labourers seem to be among the worst hit from the lockdown. Employment among these dropped from an average of 12.8 crore in last fiscal to a mere 3.7 crore in April, which means that more than 9 crore people lost their livelihood in just about a month. This category includes workers and daily wage-earning labourers whose livelihood depends everyday on a functioning economy. The impact of migration of labourers and their households has a significant impact on the social, political and economic conditions of India. The main objective of uplft is to provide job opportunities to migrant works from various states of India. As we know, from states like Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, majority of the population, i.e, around 50-70%, migrate in the hope of finding job opportunities. Most workers take up jobs in construction companies while the rest, like textile companies, do freelancing. Uplft aims to provide a structured and organised system for providing jobs to such skilled workers.
